Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation and Increasing the Success of Low-Income Students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics: A Knowledge Exchange Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This multi-disciplinary academic brokering workshop brings together Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) faculty and administrators and researchers who study higher education to address issues of financial, academic, and student support that broaden the participation and success of low-income students pursuing degrees and careers in STEM. The central purpose of the Knowledge Exchange is to develop shared approaches to generating knowledge, measuring, and describing successful evidence-based strategies to accelerate knowledge generation, and systemic and sustainable change in STEM education at the post-secondary education level. The project leverages and builds upon the efforts and infrastructures of two organizational activities of the Association of American Colleges & Universities: Project Kaleidoscope (AAC&U PKAL) and STEM Central, whose combined emphasis is on improving STEM education in higher education. The expected outcome of the workshop is to increase and strengthen the development of collaborations and formation of a community among educational/social science researchers, discipline-based researchers, and STEM faculty and administrators - committed to examining and addressing the issues associated with broadening participation and increasing the success of low income students, who are pursing associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees in STEM and seeking entry into the STEM workforce.

The evaluation of the effort has two aims: the first examines the extent of knowledge exchange that occurs between a diverse group of invited participants; and the second considers the quality of the information being made available to the wider STEM education community and its capacity to impact STEM teaching behavior. The mixed method outcomes-based evaluation is guided by prior research into how knowledge is exchanged within interdisciplinary groups. To that end, the evaluation of the Knowledge Exchange will assess the degree to which the project is able to facilitate the exchange of successful strategies relevant to the undergraduate education of low-income STEM students and the subsequent implementation of those strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If the nation is to meet its demand for STEM talent, faculty from many different disciplines must be meaningfully involved and their disciplinary traditions and epistemologies must be fully embraced. AAC&U’s National Knowledge Exchange project was launched in 2016 to facilitate an evidence-based information exchange between and among STEM disciplinary faculty, social scientists, and education researchers in order to build the capacity of the undergraduate STEM reform communities they occupy to develop a common language and viewpoint for determining how best to substantially increase the success of academically talented, low-income students in STEM disciplines. To achieve this, the project has utilized the academic brokering capacity of AAC&U to implement strategies that were deeply grounded in a novel conceptual framework that utilized culturally responsive inquiry to guide undergraduate STEM education research and practice. Specifically, these strategies included: interdisciplinary meetings, focus group discussions, online webinars, and a robust dissemination plan. The outcome of our implementing these strategies is represented by the integration of elements of STEM education research into our national STEM Conference infrastructure – leading to a permanent change in our structure for national undergraduate STEM reform. Yet another important outcome of this project is the conceptualization of a framework that blends the inclusive excellence agenda of AAC&U, its commitment to STEM reform, and the goals of the current project. This conceptual framework – culturally responsive inquiry-based research, or CIBR – now offers AAC&U a mechanism for not only sustaining elements of the current project, but also institutionalizing them into other areas of the organization’s structure. In sum, the activities of this project, which brought together both STEM disciplinary faculty and education researchers, has enhanced AAC&U’s STEM faculty professional development models, and created more complete ways for us to think about and approach undergraduate STEM reform at a national level. This is evident in the dramatic shifts in language contained in our conference and meeting promotions, speaker and presenter selections, as well as strategic planning for the future.
